S1.T1.caption: Table 1: Number of communication rounds that achieve 𝔼​‖∇F​(𝒙~o​u​t)‖22≤ϵ𝔼superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript~𝒙𝑜𝑢𝑡22italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla F\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_{out}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon for non-convex objectives (or 𝔼​F​(𝒙~o​u​t)−F∗≤ϵ𝔼𝐹subscript~𝒙𝑜𝑢𝑡subscript𝐹italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}F({\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_{out}})-F_{*}\leq\epsilon for PL condition or strongly-convex with the parameter of μ𝜇\mu). We optimize an online scenario and set the small batch size to 1. The symbol ✓ or ✗ for ”Partial Clients” is determined by whether full-client participation is required.
references: As the anchors are not necessary to obtain the averaged caching gradient (i.e., g~tsubscript~𝑔𝑡\tilde{g}_{t}) at t𝑡t-th round, the centralized server solely distributes g~tsubscript~𝑔𝑡\tilde{g}_{t} to the miners. Compared to FedAvg, the proposed algorithm requires (1−pt)/21subscript𝑝𝑡2(1-p_{t})/2 more communication costs, but it achieves convergence with at least O​(1ϵ)𝑂1italic-ϵO(\frac{1}{\epsilon}) less communication rounds (see Table 1). Therefore, from the perspective of model training progress, FedAMD is more communication efficient than FedAvg.

As discussed in Section 3, FedAMD reduces to BVR-L-SGD (Murata & Suzuki, 2021) when τ=2𝜏2\tau=2 and all clients participate in the training. In this case, Corollary 4.5 shows a total of T=O​(1/ϵ)𝑇𝑂1italic-ϵT=O(1/\epsilon) communication rounds are needed. This result coincides with the complexity of BVR-L-SGD in Table 1 by the setting that (1) n​M≤1ϵ𝑛𝑀1italic-ϵnM\leq\frac{1}{\epsilon}, and (2) K≥n/M𝐾𝑛𝑀K\geq\sqrt{n/M}. In other words, we theoretically prove that BVR-L-SGD still achieves mint∈[T]⁡‖∇F​(𝒙~t)‖22≤ϵsubscript𝑡delimited-[]𝑇superscriptsubscriptnorm∇𝐹subscript~𝒙𝑡22italic-ϵ\min_{t\in[T]}\left\|\nabla F\left(\tilde{\boldsymbol{x}}_{t}\right)\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq\epsilon with T=O​(1/ϵ)𝑇𝑂1italic-ϵT=O(1/\epsilon) in a looser constraint. As for computation overhead, our proposed method requires O​(σ2ϵ2+M​Kϵ)𝑂superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑀𝐾italic-ϵO\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{MK}{\epsilon}\right), which is less than BVR-L-SGD (i.e., O​(σ2ϵ2+σ2+M​Kϵ+M​K)𝑂superscript𝜎2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜎2𝑀𝐾italic-ϵ𝑀𝐾O\left(\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\epsilon^{2}}+\frac{\sigma^{2}+MK}{\epsilon}+MK\right)).

references: Table 2 compares FedAMD with the existing works under partial/full client participation. At first glance, FedAMD outperforms other baselines because the texts in bold are all appeared in FedAMD. With 20-client participation, our proposed method surpasses four baselines all aroundness. As for 40-client participation, FedAMD with constant probability saves at least 30% computation and communication cost, and the final accuracy realizes up to 6% improvement. In terms of the training with full client participation, FedAMD requires 10%–20% fewer communication rounds, and its final accuracy has significant improvement, i.e., within the range of 0.7%–8.3%. Also, it is well noted that BVR-L-SGD has a similar performance as FedAMD using sequential probability in terms of communication rounds and test accuracy, but the former needs more computation and communication overhead. This is because BVR-L-SGD computes the bullseye using multiple b′superscript𝑏′b^{\prime}-size batches rather than a large batch.
